awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Development of a smart food distribution software system
awd_abstract_narration:
The commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a decision-support system for humanitarian food relief networks which harnesses complex data to support large-scale distribution and resource allocation decisions.  The human decision-making process is supported by intelligent autonomous agents that guide users through data modeling and visualization tasks tailored to the specific needs of the organization considering their specific objectives of 1) equitable allocation of resources; 2) cost effective distribution of resources; and 3) efficient use of scarce resources.  Scarce resource allocation problems in humanitarian food relief networks consist of human (volunteer resources) and material (e.g., food, money). The commercial potential lies at the ability to make model-specific recommendations to decision-makers based on the agent's capability to learn from the user environment through data and human/computer interaction. The proposed system bridges the knowledge gap between sophisticated modeling tools and operations subject matter experts who may benefit from these tools but lack the domain-specific knowledge to implement them in practice.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a platform for humanitarian food relief networks that possesses machine learning and optimization capabilities interwoven with the human cognition capabilities. Specifically, the proposed technology leverages research in cognitive computing and data modeling to build an intelligent platform to empower organizations to integrate advanced data modeling into their operations. The vision is that this platform will function as a collection of intelligent agents supporting workers performing different functions as a team. In this context, intelligence implies the following four cognitive abilities: to remember and process large amounts of information, to visualize and understand complex concepts in the information, to communicate (e.g., provide instruction and guidance), and to learn from experience. The platform is designed to contain a robust operations and data modeling ontology to facilitate human/machine interaction of the intelligent agents with the team of workers and to facilitate the execution of the four cognitive abilities. This I-Corps team plans to investigate the market potential of this innovation, validate customer needs and how the innovation may alleviate such needs, and discern sustainable business models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
The ICorps project associated with the NSF PFI:BIC - Flexible, Equitable, Efficient, and Effective Distribution (FEEED) grant focused on customer discovery in order to clarify the product value proposition, the key customers, and the needs of these key stakeholders. This was accomplished in part through over 110 customer discovery interviews. The majority of these interviews were conducted with hunger relief organizations, primarily food banks. Our project develops a smart service system to assist hunger relief organizations, like food banks, in the Flexible, Equitable, Efficient, and Effective Distribution (FEEED) of food to those in need. Therefore, we envision that the primary customers for our ICorps project are non profit organizations focused on food rescue including the collection and distribution of donated surplus food. We also conducted interviews with healthcare organizations and school systems as they both consider the equitable distribution of limited resources similar to hunger relief organizations and could be a future growth area for our project.

 

Our customer discovery process resulted in an extensive study of food banks and other hunger relief organizations across the country capturing the impact of COVID-19 and the resulting supply chain disruptions on food rescue operations across the country. These interviews revealed several themes across the country as well as significant heterogeneity among the organizations’ operations and the differential food insecurity needs across the country (e.g., differing levels of access to not just food but also running water). As one of the interviewees highlighted: “There is enough food to feed everyone in America. The challenge is to get the food to the people in need.” The interviewees identified challenges with logistics, challenges with understanding need down to the neighborhood level, and the paradox of food rescue in that there is both food insecurity and food waste. One of the consistent themes was related to data and the inability to meaningfully translate data to inform decision making. The organizations consistently emphasized the importance of the data and the need to make data driven decisions in order to meet the food rescue challenges. However, many, in fact most indicated they did not have the resources (human and technology) to analyze data. The interviews highlighted a transition in hunger relief operations that emphasized the needs of our food insecure neighbors. The interviews revealed the importance of (i) the type of food provided, (ii) ensuring access to fresh produce, culturally relevant food, and medically meaningful food, and (iii) considering the needs of our neighbors. Data and data analytics were identified as a critical enabling driver of accomplishing these goals. Hunger relief organizations need a fast way to aggregate information from multiple sources to understand each aspect of their operations (demand, staff, volunteers, distribution) to facilitate managing food distribution activities. This requires the ability to aggregate information from multiple manual and automated data sources to provide central visibility to operations. 

 A critical aspect of entering the hunger relief marketplace was to develop a relationship with Feeding America (the largest hunger relief organization in the US). Through our customer discovery process we have established a relationship with leadership within Feeding America. As a result, we have worked with them on a project to characterize the food rescue landscape including for profit and nonprofit organizations. We conducted a SWOT analysis in the food rescue space informing Feeding America’s perception of this space and further informing our understanding of this market. Our findings from our ICorps project have not just informed our FEEED project market analysis but provide significant insights regarding the current state of hunger relief and food insecurity in the US as well as the challenges faced by food rescue organizations.  

 

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Lauren Davis

The ICorps project associated with the NSF PFI:BIC - Flexible, Equitable, Efficient, and Effective Distribution (FEEED) grant focused on customer discovery in order to clarify the product value proposition, the key customers, and the needs of these key stakeholders. This was accomplished in part through over 110 customer discovery interviews. The majority of these interviews were conducted with hunger relief organizations, primarily food banks. Our project develops a smart service system to assist hunger relief organizations, like food banks, in the Flexible, Equitable, Efficient, and Effective Distribution (FEEED) of food to those in need.
